docs.snippet: " The President-not the army- is the enemy," says an informal spokesman for a group of medical students. For two weeks, the students have been marching in peaceful demonstrations and distributing leaflets against the "dictatorship," and now that they...
docs.lead_paragraph: " The President-not the army- is the enemy," says an informal spokesman for a group of medical students. For two weeks, the students have been marching in peaceful demonstrations and distributing leaflets against the "dictatorship," and now that they have
docs.abstract: spokesmen for group of med students, frustrated by ending of 15-day gen strike against Pres J M Bordaberry's closing of Cong, say Pres and not mil is enemy; say mil regimes can be progressive as well as fascist; would not be opposed to mil regime that could effect social and econ change needed in Uruguay; see crisis in country arising from struggle between alliance of foreign and native capital and forces of workers; though med union remained passive during strike, its members are in sympathy with Tupamaro guerrillas; students see themselves threatened by new Educ Min E Narancio, conservative historian, who was once expelled from his university and is now planning university changes

headline.main: Uruguayan Students Say President, Not the Army, Is the Enemy; Of Regimes Good and Bad

docs.snippet: TO THE EDITOR: JUDGING from his article of June 24, Theodore C. Sorensen is in trouble with "State of Siege": he likes the movie, but he can't stand what he thinks it tells him about A.I.D. policies in South America. No doubt,
docs.lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR: JUDGING from his article of June 24, Theodore C. Sorensen is in trouble with "State of Siege": he likes the movie, but he can't stand what he thinks it tells him about A.I.D. policies in South America. No doubt,
docs.abstract: J Yglesias lr disputes T Sorensen article on film 'State of Siege,' says Sorensen cannot see film clearly because he is blind to any unpleasant aspects of Pres Kennedy's AID program; says Tupamaros did not 'murder' D A Mitrione but executed him

headline.main: Did Sorensen Face Facts?; Movie Mailbag

docs.snippet: As recently as 1960, Uruguay was a showcase of democracy, with a vigorous two-party system modeled partly on that of the United States and a military as uninvolved in government as the armies of Denmark or Switzerland. Now Uruguay's elected President...
docs.lead_paragraph: As recently as 1960, Uruguay was a showcase of democracy, with a vigorous two-party system modeled partly on that of the United States and a military as uninvolved in government as the armies of Denmark or Switzerland. Now Uruguay's elected President has closed down Congress, put an end to constitutional rule and inaugurated a military-controlled regime.
docs.abstract: G MacEoin article revs role of mil in South Amer; sees atom bomb as critical agent in transformation of mil's view of mission from that of defenders of nation from external threat to that of defenders of democratic institutions from Communism within; sees mil divided into 2 factions: 'gorilas' (gorillas), who defend status quo, and 'nationalists' who believe mil govt can introduce social reforms; applies division to situation in Brazil, Bolivia, Uruguay and Peru; sees even nationalists as inadequate to creation of stable and just society; map of South Amer showing various types of mil regimes

headline.main: Looking for New Fields To Conquer; The Latin Generals

docs.snippet: The Senate confirmed today the nominations of John L. McLucas as Secretary of the Air Force and Gen. George S. Brown as Air Force chief of staff. Action was by voice vote without dissent.

docs.snippet: The Uruguayan opposition has opened a new phase of resistance to the installation of a military dictatorship in that country with a strong democratic tradition, according to an
docs.lead_paragraph: The Uruguayan opposition has opened a new phase of resistance to the installation of a military dictatorship in that country with a strong democratic tradition, according to an
docs.abstract: Uruguyan Sen E Erro, whose alleged support of Tupamaros precipitated conflict between Pres J M Bordaberry and Cong that led to closing of Cong, says from exile in Argentina on July 15 that resistence to mil dictatorship in Uruguay has entered new phase with failure of 15-day gen strike; it must now organize in countryside which was generally apathetic or even favorable to Bordaberry's authoritarian measures; says unions will resume strikes but only where they are strong enough to resist Govt pressure; says he, Sen W Ferreira Aldunate of National party and 4 other congressmen from main opposition parties have set up com in Argentina to coordinate resistence; com has begun propaganda campaign among 110,000 Uruguayans living in Argentina and among Argentines themselves who are concerned about Brazilian influence in Uruguay; Erro says Brazilian mil offered financial aid and gasoline during gen strike; says his campaign's principle slogan is: 'Our Country will not be Brazilianized'

headline.main: URUGUAY SENATOR LEADS RESISTANCE; Erro Opposes Military Coup From Argentine Exile Leader of Left Coalition

byline.original: By MARVINE HOWESpecial to The New York Times

docs.snippet: It's only 120 miles from Montevideo to Sauce de Yl but it's a journey to a different and distinctly calmer world.
docs.lead_paragraph: It's only 120 miles from Montevideo to Sauce de Yl but it's a journey to a different and distinctly calmer world.
docs.abstract: Article, discussing rural Uruguayans reaction to present pol crisis in country, notes that farmers are apathetic to crisis; rancher J J Methol discusses needs for agr reforms; notes that present pol crisis in country is economically oriented; says that life of farmers has not suffered much because generally they have been on bottom of econ scale; points out that farmers' life actually has improved; Methol illus

headline.main: 120 Miles From Capital, a Rural Uruguayan Asks, 'What Crisis?'; Apartment in the City Favors Land Reform High Cost of Machinery

docs.snippet: Cuba's Premier, Fidel Castro, has accused the United States of using the "most reactionary and corrupt regimes" in Latin America to isolate the continent's progressive governments.
docs.lead_paragraph: Cuba's Premier, Fidel Castro, has accused the United States of using the "most reactionary and corrupt regimes" in Latin America to isolate the continent's progressive governments.
docs.abstract: Cuban Premier F Castro on July 26 accuses US of using 'most reactionary and corrupt regimes' in Latin Amer to isolate continent's progressive govts; names Brazil, Bolivia, Paraguay and Uruguay as 'most unconditional pawns of US; calls OAS tool of Amer imperialism

headline.main: U.S. Using Latin 'Pawns,' Castro Says; O.A.S. Criticized
